questions.question: Which of the given instrument's tip resembles the given image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Rampley's Sponge Holding Forceps Explanation: Rampley's Sponge Holding Forceps are designed with tips that have a specific shape ideal for gripping sponges or swabs securely. These tips often feature serrations. Rampley's Sponge Holding Forceps (Option B) I Designed in a scissor-like configuration, featuring ratcheted handles with serrated looped jaws. Used to handle gauze or sponges. Used to hold gall bladder/cervix/tongue, etc. during operative procedures. Mayo's Towel Clip (Option A ruled out) I Cross-action tip: no approximation. Used to secure drapes in the surgical area. Used to attach suction tubes, diathermy wires, and laparoscopic cables to the operating table. Used to stabilise ribs in cases of flail chest. Doyen's Towel Clip (Option D ruled out) I A short instrument with curved ends with sharp points. The handles connect at the proximal ends. Tension blades open when pressed and vice versa. Moynihan's Tetra-Towel clip (Option C ruled out) I Has two teeth on each blade. Attaches cut edges of a skin incision to the corners of draped tetra towels to isolate the surgical area. Alternatively, isolation can be done by suturing the draped edges to subcutaneous tissue or using an adhesive plastic drape with a pre-made incision.

questions.question: Match the following Blade numbers with their uses given. 1. No. 11 a) Skin incisions in major surgeries 2. No. 12 b) Used in plastic surgery 3. No. 15 c) Incision and drainage of abscesses 4. No. 22 d) Used for tonsillectomy
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a Explanation: Blade Number Use No. 11 Stab knife, used for incision and drainage of abscesses, and small incisions (e.g., drains). No. 12 Curved blade, used for tonsillectomy; cutting edge faces the surgeon. No. 15 Used in plastic surgery, head and neck surgeries, and facial surgeries. Nos. 20, 22, 24 Used for skin incisions in major surgeries like laparotomy, thoracotomy, craniotomy, and limb surgeries. The Bard-Parker (BP) handle is a flat stainless steel instrument with slots on both sides for attaching scalpel blades. The BP handle is sterilized using an autoclave. For each patient, a new blade is inserted into the handle to ensure sharpness.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.A: The needle holder is sterilized by an autoclave.
options.B: Toothed dissecting forceps are used to hold delicate structures like nerves and vessels.
options.C: Curved needle holders provide better maneuverability in deep areas like the pelvis.
options.D: Plain non-toothed dissecting forceps are used to hold friable structures like peritoneum and tendons.

questions.explanation: vessels. Correct Answer: B) Toothed dissecting forceps are used to hold delicate structures like nerves and vessels. Explanation: INSTRUMENT DESCRIPTION NEEDLE HOLDER FORCEPS Small distal blades with criss-cross serrations and a groove for grip. Length of handle: Blade Ratio : 4:1. Types : Straight or curved Needle Positioning : Needle held at the junction of proximal 2/3 and distal 1/3 for control. Handling : Held between thumb and ring finger. Curved Holders : For better maneuverability in deep areas (pelvis, thorax). (Option C ruled out) Sterilization : Autoclave. (Option A ruled out) Tungsten-Carbide Coating : Increases durability. PLAIN DISSECTING FORCEPS Used to hold delicate, soft, and friable structures like peritoneum, vessels, bowel, nerves, and tendons. (Option D ruled out) Not suitable for holding skin or tough structures. Hold, fix, steady, or stretch tissues. Hold and cauterize small bleeding vessels. TOOTHED FORCEPS Used to hold skin and tough structures like fascia and aponeurosis. Not used for delicate structures like the bowel, vessels, or nerves. (Option B) May have one-in-two or two-in-three teeth. Adson’s Forceps : Small, fine forceps for delicate work; can be toothed or non-toothed. Victor–Bonney’s Forceps : Heavy-toothed dissecting forceps.

questions.question: Match the following instruments with their corresponding images: 1) a) Bone nibbler 2) b) Humby’s Knife 3) c) Rib Shear 4) d) Bone Cutter

A 60 year old male presents with rectal bleeding and a history of hemorrhoids. His physician decides to perform a proctoscopy using Kelly's rectal speculum to assess the cause of the bleeding. Which of the following is NOT an indication of the use of Kelly's rectal speculum?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C)Treating acute anal fissure Explanation: Kelly's rectal speculum is contraindicated in cases of acute anal fissure due to the potential for exacerbating the patient's pain and causing further injury. Kelly's Rectal Speculum Indications: Diagnostic : Piles (Option A ruled out) Fissure in ano Polyps Stricture Internal opening in fistula Carcinoma or any rectal bleeding (Option D ruled out) Therapeutic : Injection therapy for partial prolapse or piles (Option B ruled out) Cryotherapy for piles Banding for piles Polypectomy Biopsy for carcinoma rectum or anorectum. Contraindications: Acute anal fissures (Option C) Parts: Shape : Conical, with a larger proximal diameter (3.5 cm) than the distal (2.5 cm) for better light reflection. Length : Typically 10 cm. Obturator : Inner part that facilitates easy insertion. Proximal Flange : Funnel-shaped, 5 cm in diameter Positions for Proctoscopy Left lateral position- Common Right lateral Lithotomy Knee-elbow position

questions.question: A 45 year old woman undergoes surgery for varicose veins involving the stripping of the long saphenous vein using a Mayo vein stripper. Post-operatively, she complains of pain and tingling along the medial aspect of her leg. Which nerve is most commonly damaged during the stripping of the long saphenous vein?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Saphenous nerve Explanation: The saphenous nerve runs along the path of the long saphenous vein and is susceptible to injury during stripping procedures, leading to saphenous neuralgia. MAYO VEIN STRIPPER: Mayo Vein Stripper Uses: Primarily used for removal of varicose veins, typically the long saphenous vein. Employed when the vein is severely damaged, often due to varicose veins. Procedure: Insertion: The Mayo vein stripper is passed through an incision made just below the saphenofemoral junction. Stripping : The instrument is threaded through the vein, usually stripping up to the middle of the leg. Ligation : The damaged vein is tied off (ligated) or completely removed, depending on the condition of the vein. Complications: Saphenous neuralgia (nerve pain). Saphenous nerve injury is the most common complication after surgical treatment of varicose veins. Endothermal ablation The endothermal ablation procedure involves threading a small laser fibre into the vein at the failure location. Following local anesthesia, blood flow is obstructed by irritating the vein wall and allowing the vein to close. The vein eventually disappears and is no longer visible on the surface of the leg. There are two types of endothermal ablation: endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) and radiofrequency ablation (RFA) Sciatic nerve (Option A) : Unlikely to be damaged as it runs posteriorly in the thigh, far from the saphenous vein. Tibial nerve (Option B) : Unlikely to be affected since it is located in the posterior compartment of the leg, not near the saphenous vein. Femoral nerve (Option D) : Unlikely to be damaged during this procedure as it is located in the groin and anterior thigh, away from the path of the saphenous vein.

questions.question: Match the following instruments with their respective images: 1. Kocher’s forceps

options.A: 2. Mosquito forceps B) 3. Allis forceps C) 4. Babcock’s forceps D)

questions.question: Which of the following is used to retract the scapula during thoracotomy? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Explanation: This instrument is known as a scapula retractor. It has got a long stout handle with a broad right-angled blade with serrations. It is used to retract scapula during thoracotomy Balfour self-retaining retractor (Option A ruled out): Features adjustable blades for retracting the abdominal wall and tissues during surgery. Quadrangular metal frame with two heavy, hook-shaped side blades designed to fit into the wound sides. Includes a detachable third blade for retracting viscera. One side blade has a screw to adjust the retraction width, while the detachable blade is fixed through an adjustable screw with a slot. Inserted closed into the wound, then widened as needed Beckman Weitlaner retractor (Option D ruled out): The Beckman Weitlaner Retractor is a surgical tool that retracts tissues and skin during surgical procedures. It is most commonly used during spinal and hip surgeries. The instrument features finger ring handles along with a self-locking mechanism Scapula retractor (Option B): It has got a long stout handle with a broad right-angled blade with serrations. It is used to retract the scapula during thoracotomy. Allison Lung retractor (Option C ruled out): Long handle with light blade. The blade is made up of wires. The blade is at right angle to the handle. It is used to retract the lungs. The lung can expand between the wires of the blade. It is atraumatic. It is used in esophageal surgery, thoracic sympathectomy, and mediastinal surgery. Bladder neck retractor: It is a thin, long instrument with two thin long distal blades. Proximal thin shafts have got a ratchet. When the ratchet closes, the blades will open. It is used in retracting the bladder neck in bladder surgeries.

questions.question: Identify the following instrument:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Potts bulldog clamp Explanation: Doyen’s intestinal occlusion clamp (Option C ruled out): Have diagonal serrations with opposing blades Used to grasp and enclose delicate structures such as the intestines. These instruments are used to occlude the lumen of the intestine and the blood vessels The instrument has slightly concave jaws; therefore both ends meet only at the extreme when locked. The lumen of the intestine or vessels lies in the center of concavity ensuring sustained pressure which is just enough to occlude the lumen but not damage it. Payr’s gastric occlusion clamp (Option A ruled out): It has longitudinal serrations on the inner surface of the blades with several ball-like projections along the sides which interlock each other of the opposite blade to have a firm grip on the stomach/bowel while using. Once applied, it crushes the bowel. Light’s Bulldog clamp (Option D ruled out): Operates with a pinch cock mechanism to open and close. Features fine transverse serrations on the blades. Used to clamp vessels during vascular anastomosis, such as in AV fistula creation.

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates Mayo scissors from Metzenbaum scissors? for cutting dense tissues. for blunt dissection and fine tissue work. in thoracic surgeries. delicate and used for blunt dissection

options.A: Mayo scissors are designed for delicate dissection while Metzenbaum scissors are sturdy and suited
options.B: Mayo scissors are sturdy and suitable for cutting dense tissues, while Metzenbaum scissors are ideal
options.C: Metzenbaum scissors are used for cutting dense tissues, while Mayo scissors are for blunt dissection
options.D: Metzenbaum scissors are suitable for cutting sutures and are sturdy, whereas Mayo scissors are

questions.explanation: Metzenbaum scissors are ideal for blunt dissection and fine tissue work. Correct Answer: B) Mayo scissors are sturdy and suitable for cutting dense tissues, while Metzenbaum scissors are ideal for blunt dissection and fine tissue work. Explanation: Mayo scissors are designed to handle dense and tough tissues, making them suitable for procedures like appendectomy and mastectomy. Metzenbaum scissors, on the other hand, are designed for more delicate tasks such as blunt dissection and cutting fine tissues. Scissors Type Design Uses Alternative Names Mayo Scissors Sturdy and robust, suitable for cutting dense tissues. Appendectomy. Herniotomy. Exploratory laparotomy. Mastectomy. Gynecological surgeries (e.g., dissecting tendons, and uterus structures). Cutting ligaments (e.g., laryngectomy, thyroidectomy). Often called "suture scissors". Metzenbaum Scissors Delicate and ideal for blunt dissection. Blunt dissection. Incising deep rib bed periosteum in thoracic procedures. Tonsillectomy Commonly known as "Metz" or "Lahey forceps". Lister Bandage Scissors Features a longer, blunt-tipped bottom blade paired with an angled sharp upper blade for secure and precise cutting. Cutting bandages on the skin. Dressings. -

questions.question: Which of the following instruments is used to assess the patency of CBD?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Bakes Dilator Explanation: Summary of Dilation Instruments: Instrument Description Primary Use Bakes Dilator / Bakes bile duct dilator (Option A) A long, malleable, metallic instrument with a club-shaped tip. Assessing patency/blockage of the CBD and duodenal papilla. Tracheal Dilator (Option B ruled out) Used to widen the tracheal opening during tracheostomy. Facilitates insertion of a tracheostomy tube. Urethral Dilator (Option C ruled out) A long, curved, metallic instrument with a blunt tip. Urethral dilation. Filiform Bougies (Option D) : These are thin, cylindrical instruments used for navigating strictures and do not have a club-shaped tip.

questions.question: Which laparoscopic instrument is used to establish pneumoperitoneum?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Veress Needle Explanation: The Veress needle is specifically designed to establish pneumoperitoneum by creating a space in the abdominal cavity for laparoscopic procedures. It uses a sharp outer bevel to penetrate the abdominal wall and a blunt inner stylet to prevent injury to internal organs. Summary of Laparoscopic Instruments: Instrument Description Primary Use Veress Needle (Option B) Spring-loaded with a sharp outer bevel and blunt inner stylet. Inserted at Palmer's point (3 cm below the left costal margin). Establishes pneumoperitoneum for laparoscopic procedures. Hasson Cannula/Trocar (Option A ruled out ) A blunt-tipped trocar is inserted through a surgically created opening, typically at the umbilicus. Used for open technique access in laparoscopy. Trocar (Secondary) (Option D ruled out ) Inserted under direct laparoscopic vision after pneumoperitoneum is established. Smaller diameters are preferred. Allows insertion of additional instruments. Laparoscopic Camera (Option C) Provides a magnified, real-time view of the surgical field. Visualises the surgical field during laparoscopic surgery.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the safety protocols for electrosurgery using diathermy?

options.A: Always use the maximum current setting to ensure effectiveness and minimize burns.
options.B: Bipolar diathermy is preferred in patients with implants.
options.C: Monopolar diathermy is preferred near vital & sensitive structures.
options.D: There is no need to use smoke extractors as the risk of exposure to surgical smoke is minimal.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bipolar diathermy is preferred in patients with implants. Explanation: Bipolar diathermy is preferred in sensitive areas and for patients with implanted devices because it limits the current flow to the tissue between the two active electrodes, thus reducing the risk of unintended burns and ensuring a more controlled application. Monopolar Diathermy Mechanism: Electrical current flows from a single electrode (diathermy pencil) through the target tissue and returns via a large surface plate (indifferent electrode). Applications: Used for cutting and coagulation in various surgeries. Hazards Inadequate Contact : Poor contact with the indifferent electrode can cause burns. Accidental Earthing: Touching metal objects can create unintended current pathways, leading to burns. Insulation Failure: Damaged insulation on leads can cause burns. Accidental Activation: Unintentional activation or contact with metal instruments can result in burns. Bipolar Diathermy: Mechanism: Uses two active electrodes (forceps, scissors) with current flowing between them, heating only the tissue between the tips. No indifferent electrode is needed. Applications: Ideal for operating near vital structures and for patients with implanted devices. (Option C ruled out) Advantages: Enhanced safety by localizing current and reducing the risk of unintended burns. Key Considerations for Safe Electrosurgery Equipment Check: Verify settings before use. Lowest Effective Setting : Use minimal current necessary. (Option A ruled out) Caution with Metal Objects : Be careful near other metal instruments. Intermittent Use : Apply in short, controlled bursts. Bipolar Preference: Prefer bipolar in sensitive areas or for patients with implants. (Option B) Smoke Evacuation: Use smoke extractors to reduce exposure to surgical smoke. (Option D ruled out)

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given instrument?

options.A: Uses pressure and continuous bipolar energy for vessel sealing.
options.B: Achieves burst pressures over three times the normal systolic blood pressure.
options.D: Denatures collagen and elastin in vessel walls, forming a solid tissue seal.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sealing time is 8-10 seconds. Explanation: The given image is that of Ligasure. The sealing time is 2 to 4 seconds per seal. LigaSure: Technology: Uses pressure and continuous bipolar energy for vessel sealing. (Option A ruled out) Available for both laparoscopic and open surgeries since 1998. Mechanism: Applies high mechanical compression and adjusts energy delivery. Denatures collagen and elastin in vessel walls, forming a solid tissue seal upon cooling. (Option D ruled out) Efficiency: Sealing time: Quick - 2 to 4 seconds per seal. (Option C) Achieves burst pressures over three times the normal systolic blood pressure. (Option B ruled out) Enhances reliability and consistency in surgical procedures. Advantages: Reduced Blood Loss: Significantly decreases operative blood loss and procedure time compared to traditional sutures and clips. Enhanced Safety: Features feedback-controlled technology that stops energy delivery when the seal is complete, minimizing risk to surrounding tissues. Applications: Surgical Use: Effective in surgeries involving vascular pedicles (e.g., myomectomy, hysterectomy) and hemorrhoidectomy, thyroidectomies & open GI surgeries,
